data.text: Carbon Bike with Luggage for Long-Distance Bicycle Touring
For those questioning a carbon bike with luggage‚Ä¶
What bike is that? What rack do you have?
data.author: Eric Moriarty

data.text: Salsa Warbird
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: that is clean! Don't see to many Warbirds that are using the mounting options. Thanks for sharing.
data.author: Eric Moriarty

data.text: love my Salsa as well ‚≠êÔ∏è
data.author: Christophe Lautrette

data.text: I have gotten a lot of comments both negative and positive on my bike both loaded and unloaded. I have decided to use it for a variety of rides and it's been nice as long as I don't load it really heavy. It is designed to take racks, accessories, bags, fenders ect. I think it is durable but have been fairly gently on my Warbird on my bikepacking trips. I would love more feedback on suggest r d weight and distribution as I am 5'11" 180 lbs and have a large frame Warbird. So I am not the lightest rider. So far I think your setup is the cleanest I've seen and would imagine it's aerodynamic also.
data.author: Eric Moriarty

data.text: thanks Eric, but it's not my bike lol. I didn't post I just answered. I was really close to buying a Warbird. It's a great bike. I was planning to use it for light backpacking and I'm 230 pounds so I think you're more than good with what you're suggesting. There are a couple Salsa groups. Look them up. A lot of good advice on using their bikes for bikepacking.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I use panniers in back occasionally.

data.text: It would be great to know why you chose that particular bike for what looks like fully loaded touring? What adventures are you planning?

data.text: Salsa Warbird. You can go reasonably fast unloaded. Has all the mounts for touring. It's a very nice bike.

data.text: The problem is that it's simply unnecessary. The panniers will rub specific points on the carbon frame... weakening the integrity of your bicycle. Carbon bikes aren't good for fully loaded touring. Once broken... you cannot repair the bicycle. It's a wasteful investment to make a carbon touring bicycle.
data.author: Javier Col√≥n

data.text: mine was repaired . I still ride it almost daily
data.author: Rick Shaffer

data.text: I disagree. High quality carbon is VERY durable and abrasion resistant and strong. I've had my Warbird for 3 years. I've done everything from commuting daily 25 miles, gravel races to overnight bikepacking trips w it and have zero issues with the carbon fibers' integrity. It is a lot stronger than people assume. I also have tapes or shielded high use areas and where my bags may have rubbed. Mostly for the integrity of the paint though.

data.text: a "carbon" bicycle is a carbon fiber reinforced resin object. Resin is of the plastic family. Since bike weight is not a critical metric for touring I would not chose a carbon fiber reinforced resin frame.

data.text: nothing wrong with being old school. I have a hippy friend who rides old school steel and rides more mileage, is in amazing shape and has traveled extensively. His main form of transportation is a steel bike and he loves it. We often ride together and he has yet to even want to ride my Warbird. It's about enjoying the ride and also about being healthy imo. You can't replace fitness that's for sure.

data.text: I suggest take precaution on any bike for rubbing with guards on the chain ect and tape. True for carbon but it doesn't rub like and erode like a lot of ppl think.

data.text: it's a luxury that's for sure. A warbird is so fast, smooth and light that it is really nice when going long distances. I think it's pointless if you are not weight conscientious though. You loose a lot of the benefit unless you can go ultralight and that's when the Warbird shines!

data.author: Michael Maetreya Pace

data.text: so try repairing a hydroformed double butted alu tube on the road in... Central America, Asia, Africa? Or Titanium. When arguing "reparability" consider all options. In that case a steelbike without too fancy frame forming is the only way to go. Wheels and tyres... euh... 26, 27.5, 700c, whataver size and compatibility... on carbon or alu rims? V-brakes or hydraulics? Axle diameter and fixing? And spokes: all the same lenght, double butted or round, flat aeros,... not to mention gearing. Really: I would go for an all repairable (but heavy) trekking bike when I considered that; As soon as you deviate (especially on the frame)... you can egt stranded anywhere. So I ride carbon now.

Most truely remote places have few if any capability to repair bikes.

data.text: Guys I suppose you comment by experience , so I share mine, I had been bikepacking for nearly 4 years in very rugged terrain in the Andes , I did the gnarly Colorado trail last year in the same full suspension carbon fiber bike. My bike did great, frame is flawless. Just got another full suspension carbon fiber bike, looking forward for many more trips to come.
data.author: Xavier Montezuma

data.text: Just like any material, carbon can be made well or poorly, strong, or weak. Dave's point that the photo and lack of detail about any journey proves little is spot on - but it certainly doesn't mean that it won't work. I think he already said as much. I love the light weight of carbon but the feel of steel. I hate the weight of steel now that I have ridden so many carbon bikes. For a tour or more precisely, for my type of tour and how I treat bikes, carbon would be too much of a mental liability. Since you seem to know about carbon you know that even in the simplest of crashes the carbon may or may not be compromised and a scan would be the only way to definitively tell the extent of the damage. That isn't really an option while I'm touring. Not that carbon WOULD fail but how if fails is my concern. Steel bikes give a warning and a bit of a grace period. Aluminum less so but still less catastrophic than carbon. So my concern isn't that carbon isn't as strong - it is the mental debate that would rage in my head after a crash or drop. Plus, heavy duty carbon bikes generally go contrary to the reason I buy carbon bikes. I want them light and fast, not strong and heavy. My tarmac is fast but I would never tour on it. üòÖ
data.author: Stephen Lodewick

data.text: Yep for bike packing

data.author: Michael Maetreya Pace

data.text: If a carbon frame cracks in the middle of nowhere, and you have a small carbon repair kit, you are good to go. If a steel frame cracks in the middle of nowhere, I doubt you will have a welder mask, and welding mashine with youüòÅ Sure, you will find one eventualy,somewhere... If you doing weekend tours, or a few weeks tours,just load your carbon bike and go. But if you go around the world, than I would say steel. Happy riding!
data.author: Zigmas ≈†ileikis

data.text: I wouldn't be too happy with them handlebars going down a hill laden with frontal bags. I mean, say your equipment gets wet and you (Must) pack it away in same bags. Now it'll be about 80% heavier and marry this with wet and even slippery raod surfaces of which you (HAVE NEVER) been on because you are touring and basically you have set yourself up for a very dangerous situation. I suggest losing the front bags at most, at least, get wider handlebars...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: Sorry I dont agree I have cycled around 8,000kms here in NZ with drop barts just like that on a lot of hills and front bags, never felt unsafe, I guess it is wha tyou get used too.

data.text: I agree partly. But in physics you may come up a cropper. You see them magnificent men tight rope walking? Well, why do you think that they have big poles? See what I mean? But yes, you get used to it...

data.text: I took a ‚Ç¨180 Btwin (Decathlon France) over 12.000 miles around the Iberian peninsula. Then the chain needed replacing and the tyers, too. So. I BOUGHT ANOTHER EXACT MODEL from Decathlon (Corsica)and even reused the old tyres and brake blocks-For another few thousand miles. So, anyone out there going on about buying touring bikes (And constantly worrying about them being stolen as you pop into a restaurant or BnB or Supermarket) is just plain NUTS. I reckon the actual panniers on this bike cost the price of my bike!

data.text: Well, yes, that‚Äôs philosophical divide. My buddy likes fixing junk frame found in alley, plastic parts and shifters that work like crap. I prefer top of line equipment. I don‚Äôt do this motor pavement touring though, just off road wilderness tours where Decathlon junk wouldn‚Äôt survive. My pavement rides are day trips only.

data.text: could I just this MOMENT blow your pathetic arguement out of the water. DECATHLON is not a brand, it's a store that sells various 'junk'such as Nike, Salomon, Adidas, and many other brands. So, get on your knees, pal and act accordingly. YOU ARE WRONG here..
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: I know what bicycle junk Decathlon sport store sells, because I shop there for some accessories. My wife got bicycle shoes, and I found pretty good cycling jacket. But, bicycles aren‚Äôt same thing. I looked at buying a Decathlon mountain bike for my Congolese companions, but close inspection of poor part quality made for negative decision on that idea. Even top of line Decathlon products don‚Äôt meet my standard.
data.author: Ernest Alan Tufft

data.text: I cycled a Btwin 12.000 miles around the Iberian peninsula over three months. The bike cost under two hundred euros and I had panniers and a cheap decathlon 20 euro tent strapped onto the front handlebars...But, you fail to address my points about Decathlon not being a BRAND, but a store...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: Like my buddy who rides junk bikes, I do appreciate your willingness to ride junk around Iberian peninsula. It‚Äôs like driving VW bug vs Maserati sports car. Decathlon sells junk bikes. BTWIN is popular commuter bike in Girona, where I live.

data.text: oh, don't get me wrong (Which you have, obviously) I'm referring to excess baggage over long trips and getting on and off cycles and having to walk around fields to find places to camp at. A pair of Cycling shoes are very heavy when you factor them in (Because the point of having a carbon frame is primarily its weight). So, it's rather contradictory to having cycling shoes and normal footwear, too...Obviously cycling shoes do do what you say. But i've seen many a cyclist falling off on his ear with them, and this is BOUND to happen over the course of your unpredictable journying over tourain different from yours...Using cycling shoes makes one complacent.
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: cycle shoes with clips is what I choose. No question for me (45 years of touring).

data.text: What is the advantage of a carbon bike? The primary advantage of the material is that at a given stiffness, carbon fiber is significantly lighter than aluminum, steel, or titanium. Now, everyone thinks this is the Primary advantage. So, you may think I have it wrong, but the majority will think otherwise...I also mentioned the pedals, too. That doesn't concern weigh (Directly). But I hear what you say...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: - my point is, I have a carbon bike. Bought for non-loaded day rides primarily. Having decided to tour for 12 days this summer, I chose to use what I have, not buy a new bike. So this isn‚Äôt about suggesting carbon is best for touring. This is about suggesting carbon can be used for touring (in the right way).
data.author: Ben Bethell

data.text: what happens if it rains? You haven't got any mudguards. Then your stuff gets wet, your luggage becomes 80% heavier and your narrow handlebars become hazzardous and difficult to control. It's an accident waiting to happen, in my opinion. Yes, it's your bike and a great one at that. But in order to advocate for sensible bike journeying (As an educator) it's is my moral duty to check people that are intent on harming themselves. No matter their age or experience. I'm a big helmet advocate, too...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: Everything looks shiny, new and never used. I don‚Äôt think anyone doubts that you can do what you just did. I think people question what this will look like after a few months on the road. I‚Äôll be awaiting that post! Good luck! ÔøºÔøºÔøº

data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: My personal opinion based in professional experience. Background 20 years working in shops as well as some years building steel and titanium frames. I wouldn‚Äôt go the rack route on a carbon bike it‚Äôs asking for trouble. The leverage on the carbon at the points of attachment will ultimately cause a failure somewhere! I‚Äôm not saying don‚Äôt tour on a carbon bike but if you do, consider a bike packing set up with an aluminum handlebar, stem and seatpost. Try and go as light as you can. This will diminish the load on the carbon and reduce the chances of failure. Like I said, opinion from someone with extensive background touring, bikes and warranties!!
data.author: Nicholas Oquendo

data.text: I found a carbon frame with panniers very flexible especially on descents...no bueno. I am back to using a quality steel frame.

data.text: I read an article a few years back that trailers have less stress on a carbon framed bike than panniers. I put a high performance racing hub on the trailer and it rolls super nice. My bike is a Fuji Gran Fondo 1.3. I can disconnect the trailer and turn it upside down to make a seat or table when cooking. The flag post now has an American flag above the orange caution flag. I also have flashing tail lights on the trailer, bike and my helmet. Motorists can see me from a mile away. I hope you enjoy your trip. Life is better on a bike!
